description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Building a system rooted in healing and human dignity rather than oppression and punishment","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

subPages.title: Plank 7: End jails and prisons as we know them in America

pageListingInfo.title: End jails and prisons as we know them in America

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must radically reduce prison and jail populations while creating a new system premised on healing, accountability, rehabilitation, and respect for basic human rights.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: End jails and prisons as we know them in America

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Jails, prisons, and detention centers across the United States are inhumane. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As the COVID-19 pandemic laid undeniably bare, these facilities are inherently dehumanizing institutions that negatively impact nearly every aspect of an incarcerated person’s life, from mental and physical health and basic physical security to future opportunities. Approximately one in 30 people are sexually assaulted every year in these institutions. Medical needs are often unmet. Food is contaminated. Vermin infestations are common. Floors and walls are covered in blood, feces, and mucus. Many people are not permitted to visit with their loved ones, and many are deprived of exercise, fresh air, and sunlight. Between 2008 and 2019, more than 7,500 people died in local jails.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These institutions make our communities less safe while magnifying disparities based on race, sexual orientation, gender identity, and religion. Serious racial disparities are baked into nearly every aspect of the criminal-legal system, including who is jailed and imprisoned: Black people are jailed at rates more than three times that of White people, and Black men are imprisoned at a rate of more than five times that of White men. One-third of incarcerated women are lesbian or bisexual, though this group comprises only 3.5 percent of women nationwide. And, while there is little to no information on trans individuals within the criminal-legal system, research has shown extreme bias by police toward transgender-identifying individuals, particularly Black transgender individuals, which disproportionately funnels them into the criminal-legal system. Meanwhile, Muslims are 20 percent of the prison population in certain states, even though they represent less than 2 percent of the U.S. population. And American Indian/Alaska Natives are incarcerated in adult correctional facilities at more than twice the rate of White people.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The time has come to radically reduce prison and jail populations while creating a new system premised on healing, accountability, rehabilitation, and the respect for basic human rights. We must build a world in which people are given the community-based supports they need to survive and thrive.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Require state sentencing commissions to reengineer sentencing guidelines so as to dramatically reduce prison and jail populations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"End solitary confinement in all forms and by all names.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure that all basic necessities, including hygiene products, are provided free of charge.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the practice of private companies profiting off the backs of people subject to the horrors of the criminal-legal system. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: End high-tech harm and the surveillance state

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Technology must be used to help lift people up, connect them to community-based programs, and give people access to basic necessities they need to survive and thrive.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 8: Stop the privatization of justice

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the practice of private companies profiting off the backs of people subject to the horrors of the criminal-legal system. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The United States increasingly outsources the criminal-legal system to the private sector — and today, these companies profit enormously off people involved in the justice system. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"This profiteering occurs at every stage of the criminal-legal process: bail, court fees, incarceration, video calls, food services, health care, parole, and probation supervision. The United States funds its “carceral state” through fines and fees that mainly fall on low-income people, disproportionately people of color, accused of criminal activity. The scale of private industry’s involvement in the criminal-legal system is staggering: Few criminal-legal functions have ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"not","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", in some way or in some jurisdiction, been commercialized by private industry.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Companies profiting from punishment make decisions that maximize their profits, even if doing so directly conflicts with public policy goals. Worse, the costs resulting from these exploitative practices are borne by our society’s most marginalized: About one in four women in the United States — and nearly one in two Black women — have a family member in prison.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must eliminate this practice of private companies profiting off the backs of those involved in the criminal-legal system. We must build a world in which money is going to community-based organizations that support people instead of large corporations with a financial interest in maximizing the number of people subject to the horrors of the criminal-legal system.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"End all contracts with private prisons, jails, detention centers — including those housing immigrants and children — and probation corporations in both the federal and state criminal-legal systems.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure that all costs within the criminal-legal system are just and reasonable — i.e., comparable to free market prices — and prohibit kickbacks from vendors.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Require full transparency of all contracts that the government has with private corporations, including itemized costs for goods or services that are provided by private corporations and prices charged to incarcerated people or their families.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: End high-tech harm and the surveillance state

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Technology must be used to help lift people up, connect them to community-based programs, and give people access to basic necessities they need to survive and thrive.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: Support fair sentencing policy and end criminalization of immigrants

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a nation where we support all people, including those who immigrate here, instead of criminalizing and imprisoning them.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 9: End high-tech harm and the surveillance state

pageListingInfo.title: End high-tech harm and the surveillance state

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must use technology to help lift people up, connect them to community-based programs, and give people access to basic necessities they need to survive and thrive.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: End high-tech harm and the surveillance state

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Technology can be a force for good and has the power to improve people’s lives, yet it continues to play an increasingly pervasive and insidious role in the criminal-legal system. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Technologies like facial recognition, predictive policing technologies, and algorithm-based decision-making tools further threaten Black, Brown, Indigenous, low-income, and other marginalized communities. The use of these data-driven technologies, many of which rely on racially biased arrest data, reproduce, exacerbate, and entrench the existing disparities within the criminal-legal system. These technologies are promoted as being “evidence-based” and “objective” when, in reality, they reflect a wide range of underlying flaws and biases. Moreover, these tools are designed, developed, and tested under a shroud of secrecy — often passed off as “trade secrets” — that expand the reach of the criminal-legal system and hamstring impacted individuals when they seek to challenge the basis for restricting their freedom.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Statements by civil and human rights advocacy organizations have consistently explained how facial recognition, algorithmic risk assessment tools, and predictive policing technologies disproportionately harm communities of color. These statements highlight the lack of transparency, accuracy, fairness, and accountability endemic to these technologies, while underscoring the deep inequities and biases that can occur when technologies are designed and used without the voices of the most impacted by them.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a system free from the technology that furthers a criminalization- and surveillance-focused approach in our communities. We must build a system in which technology is used to help lift people up, connect them to community-based programs, and give them access to the basic necessities they need to survive and thrive.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ban the use of algorithmic decision-making software that advances pretrial detention.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Place a moratorium on or outright ban systems, software, and platforms that further entrench civil rights and civil liberties inequities in the criminal-legal system, such as facial recognition technology, aerial or drone surveillance, and algorithmic decision-making policing systems.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure that any tool that implicates suspects is not protected by trade secrets when challenged in an adversarial judicial proceeding.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Support fair sentencing policy and end criminalization of immigrants

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a nation where we support all people, including those who immigrate here, instead of criminalizing and imprisoning them.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: Abolish labor abuses, unpaid labor in prisons, and racial injustices

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must end the practice of slavery in jails and prisons while making it easier to challenge racially disparate policies in court. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 10: Dramatically reform sentencing policy and end criminalization of immigrants

pageListingInfo.title: Dramatically reform sentencing policy and end criminalization of immigrants

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a nation where we support all people, including those who immigrate here, instead of criminalizing and imprisoning them.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Support fair sentencing policy and end criminalization of immigrants

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The United States imprisons people at a higher rate than any other nation on Earth, in part because of its egregiously long sentences. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As of 2023, 531 of every 100,000 adults in the United States were behind bars. The criminal-legal system is also rife with racial disparities: Black people are five times more likely to be incarcerated than White people. These sentences rip parents from their children and devastate entire communities.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"At the same time, we criminalize those trying to immigrate to the United States in search of opportunity and a safer, more prosperous life for their families. Once here, we subject these valuable members of our community to constant threat of deportation and criminalization. We must end the practice of jailing, criminalizing, and inhumanely deporting those who come here from other countries.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a world in which we severely limit punishment and support all people, including those who immigrate here from other countries, instead of criminalizing and imprisoning them.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Establish commissions to review all felonies and misdemeanors to determine if they can be decriminalized or reclassified downward.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Abolish the death penalty and end life without parole sentences. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Decriminalize behaviors that are not best addressed through the criminal-legal system, such as drug possession, sex work, and crimes that stem from substance use, mental illness, or homelessness.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Abolish labor abuses, unpaid labor in prisons, and racial injustices

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must end the practice of slavery in jails and prisons while making it easier to challenge racially disparate policies in court. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: Support the children of incarcerated parents

text.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must create a world where children with an incarcerated parent are provided with adequate community-based supports and families can remain together.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

subPages.title: Plank 11: Ease legal challenges to address racial inequity and abolish slavery in prisons

pageListingInfo.title: Ease legal challenges to address racial inequity and abolish slavery in prisons

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must end the practice of slavery in jails and prisons while making it easier to challenge racially disparate policies in court. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Abolish labor abuses, unpaid labor in prisons, and racial injustices

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A just society cannot exist when its most marginalized members are forced to perform unpaid or extremely underpaid labor for large corporations and governments. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The 13th Amendment, ratified in 1865, says: “Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.” The italicized phrase, known as the “exception clause,” has contributed to a prison-industrial complex that incarcerates Black people at five times the rate of White people, while profiting from their unpaid and/or underpaid labor. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"After passage of the 13th Amendment, Black Codes in the South created offenses that were intentionally vague, sending more Black people to prison than ever before. At the same time, many states put people in prison to work through the brutal and inhumane practice known as “convict-leasing” — a practice that allowed White plantation owners and industrialists to “lease” people in prison to work for them (against their will and for no pay) decades after the end of the Civil War. States also benefited from this free labor by forcing people to work on “chain gangs” building roads and growing crops on prison farms. This practice continues in various forms today.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s more, decisions in other areas have made equity-based challenges to exploitative, racialized practices difficult. Impossibly high bars to legal challenges, like the failure to consider “disparate impact” an acceptable basis for 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause claims, has foreclosed legal challenges that could help combat racial injustice. We must end the practice of slavery in jails and prisons while making it easier to challenge racially disparate policies in court.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support a constitutional amendment that would eliminate the “exception clause” of the 13th Amendment, which continues to allow involuntary servitude in U.S. prisons and jails.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support the establishment of a federal commission to study and develop reparation proposals for African Americans, including legislation like H.R. 40, the Commission to Study and Develop Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Repeal the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 1996 and the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 and completely abolish qualified immunity.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo2.title: End inhumane conditions in jails and prisons in the United States

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must radically reduce prison and jail populations while creating a new system premised on healing, accountability, rehabilitation, and respect for basic human rights.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 12: Support the children of incarcerated parents

pageListingInfo.title: Support the children of incarcerated parents

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must create a world where children with an incarcerated parent are provided with adequate community-based supports and families can remain together.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Support the children of incarcerated parents

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Today, one in 28 children has an incarcerated parent; almost one-fifth of these kids are under age four. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"One in nine Black children has an incarcerated parent. More than 5 million children have had a parent behind bars in the past. This separation takes a profound toll: Kids with incarcerated parents tend to underperform academically and are more likely to drop out of school. They’re at higher risk of experiencing anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, and behavioral issues. Put simply, having an incarcerated parent is a traumatic experience. And, as research shows, traumatic experiences during childhood have lifelong effects.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must reduce the number of children with incarcerated parents by drastically reducing the number of parents incarcerated in the first place. Those children who experience parental incarceration can still thrive and succeed but they need the support to do so. We must create a world in which these children are provided with adequate community-based supports — affordable mental and physical health care, high-quality education, extracurricular activities, etc. — and the opportunity for ample in-person visits with their incarcerated parent. We must create a world in which families can remain together.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Allow parents to spend the last 18 months of their sentence in programs and classes that prepare them for reentry and reunification with their children.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Codify the right to in-person, contact visits and substantially improve the visiting experience through innovative, people-centered changes to visiting facilities, procedures, and programming — without increasing corrections budgets.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Offer free video conferencing, email, and phone calls to allow children to stay connected with a parent in between in-person visits.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: End inhumane conditions in jails and prisons in the United States

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must eliminate the practice of private companies profiting off the backs of people subject to the horrors of the criminal-legal system. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
